title: For adults. Do some of you miss high school now even when you were complaining during your teenage years how you hate going to school? Do those adults who told you 'you're gonna miss high school when you'll have bills to pay' were right? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. I have never missed school in the 16 years after I left. Not once. On the contrary, when I read YA or watch a film with high school drama or teenage angst I again give thanks that I am no longer in high school or a teenager. Here’s the thing: you choose the bills you pay. We chose our phones, our phone plans, our streaming service(s), the cars we drive and the home we bought. We choose what we buy (and what shows up on our credit cards). We also chose the jobs we apply for which enable us to pay these bills. Is paying bills and taxes fun? No Is life expensive? Yes Do you sometimes wish you had more money for fun stuff and didn't have to pay so much for insurance, gas, electricity and water and other things to stay alive and housed? For sure. Is adulting hard? Yes. Would I ever consider giving it up in favor for going back to high school? NO! Not only no, but [insert expletive] no. Not in a million years. I thought the adults who said those things were full of it when I was a teenager. I was right.

A most emphatic NO! Permit me to set the stage for you. From the time I was 12 until I graduated high school I was incarcerated in a “boarding school” for the high crime of being an orphan. Yes they fed me (poorly). They housed me in wooden barracks filled with saggy metal frame bunk beds. The local public school sent a bus to pick us up every school day for a rather questionable education. On the downside, punishment for infractions of the rules were barbaric by standards of this century. A small percentage of my fellow inmates were socially maladjusted to the point of needing to be removed from polite society. A larger percentage of the staff fell into that category. Put yourself in that situation and your high school diploma is a true ticket to freedom. I rather enjoy having the liberty to decide which services I want to partake of and therefore which bills to pay. Never again would I want to relegate that job to anyone else.

Yes and yes. High school is exponentially easier than adult life. But… high school isn’t exactly easy for everyone, either. And it was particularly hard on me. So they weren’t right in those exact words. But in a more general sense, yes. I have a lot of regrets from adolescence. Many I’ve been struggling to come to terms with for the last 30 years. Had I done it “correctly”, then yes. I would miss it just like all the adults said I would. Instead, I miss it in the sense that I did it poorly. With ignorance and arrogance. It has held me back in certain areas for much of my adult life. I regret that I missed out on a lot of opportunities as a result. And I can’t go back and change it.

Anyone who says “Schooldays were the happiest days of my life” (or words to that effect) must have a very sad life. I left school at 17…left home at 18 and never once looked back. No regrets at leaving school or my parents’ home, no regrets about any decision I made as an adult. At 71 I can look back and wish some things had been different..of course. Winning the lottery would be nice but hey…I could have done without polio at 3 but then that wasn’t my choice!

No way.. and hell no. I don’t, and have never missed high school. I even managed to graduate half a year early, and only had 3 classes my senior year. This was not because I was some genius.. no, it was because we moved before my last year of high school, and the new state we moved to had a different credit system.. lol. I think I just scooted by there.. man, I hated high school except for art and design/drafting classes. I was already working, and was glad to move on!

I miss my old friends and the crazy things we did. I had a blast in band and summer band camps. I never ‘hated’ school. As soon as I graduated high school, I got a loan for college and started working about a year later part time so I could live off campus - I didn’t have on campus housing available to me. If you are mature, you look ahead, not back to something you’ve already outgrown.

No. I am much more suited to the routine of working. Was it rough going to college and pinching expenses? Yeah. I love my job and it doesn't feel like work most days, and the paycheck I get affords me a lifestyle I'm quiet happy with. I have my own place, I make my own rules, and I get to do things on my own time and pace with that income. Not everyone peaks in high school. Some of us keep going.

I don’t miss High School or Community College (didn’t have any friends at either and was teased for being hearing impaired), but I do miss my four year school all the time. It’s been 15 years since I graduated, but I miss it horribly every August, when I “smell” fall, and even when I walk through snow (this was Fredonia, 30 miles west of Buffalo).

I don't miss high school. It was kinda like getting my wisdom teeth removed. I can accept that it was the best option available to me - but I wouldn't want to do it again. I find it very disturbing to think that some people miss high school. Most people live another 60 or 70 years after high school. That is a long life of disappointment if you peaked during high school.

Hell to the no. I was an art geek/music and a guyliner goth at that. (Pre Emo) Let’s just say I wasn’t fully embraced by the football team. Oh no. I’m good with it if I’m honest. It’s part of who I believe I am. In some ways I feel like I dodged a bit of unneeded drama. I’m happy most days. So, cheers.

There are some parts I miss. I miss how carefree my life was. How bright and exciting life was back then. But at the same time I don’t miss not having my own money, constantly being told what to do, the rat race to get into college and other things. It’s a tossup. You should be happy with your life through various ages. Different cool things come along and you appreciate them.

It's been 23 years since 1997, and I still have a bitter taste in my mouth because of my high school experience. I would seriously rather be up to my eyeballs in bills until the day I die than have to sit through another day of high school.

I don’t miss high school at all, but I really miss my college. I had the best time of my life during then, I met amazing people and had the most Inspiring professors. I truly wish to go back to my institution one day and teach a course there.

I would rather work than go back to high school. I don’t miss my school days at all. Totally forgettable. Don’t mistake me: I hate both work and school. But at least I got paid by going to work. That makes a huge difference.

I could hardly wait to finish high school and never look back. It was boring; real life is interesting. I was talked into attending the 40th reunion. After about 45 min it became just as boring as high school.
I loved my high school life and pretty much miss it time to time (yeah, I got lucky and had a great time more often then not). And yes those adults were definitely right at least in my case.
Yes. And yes. The reason, though, that I didn’t enjoy high school, was that I didn’t allow myself to. Now I know better, but it’s a bit late. ;-)
